name: Family Therapy
summary: A form of psychotherapy that helps families improve communication, resolve conflicts, and strengthen relationships by addressing patterns of interaction within the family system.
description: Family Therapy is a structured therapeutic approach that focuses on improving the functioning of families by examining relational dynamics and communication patterns. Unlike individual therapy, family therapy involves multiple family members working together with a therapist to identify problematic interactions and develop healthier ways of relating. It may draw on systemic, structural, strategic, or integrative models depending on the family's needs. The goal is to support family members in understanding one another, resolving conflicts, and enhancing coping strategies for challenges such as mental illness, behavioral problems, or life transitions.

equipment_required: None beyond therapist space or teletherapy platform

off_label_uses: Support during medical treatment of a family member
contraindications: Unwilling participation of critical family members
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe, but may temporarily heighten tension when discussing sensitive issues.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Meta-analyses show family therapy improves communication, reduces relapse in schizophrenia, and enhances outcomes in adolescent behavioral disorders.

sections.text: Family therapy works by addressing the relational dynamics within a family system. Therapists observe patterns of communication, roles, and interactions, then guide the family toward healthier exchanges. By restructuring dysfunctional patterns and promoting empathy, families can resolve conflicts and support one another more effectively.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment of family members, relationships, and presenting issues. Goals are collaboratively set.
procedure: Family sessions led by a therapist (sometimes co-therapists).
Use of systemic techniques to identify problematic patterns.
Practice of new communication strategies and problem-solving skills.

sections.pre_session: Therapist reviews previous progress and checks in with all family members.
sections.treatment_phase: Active work on communication, role dynamics, and problem-solving.
sections.post_session: Summary of progress, feedback, and practice assignments.

rare: Escalation of conflict without therapist mediation

relative: One or more key members refusing to participate

ideal_candidates: Families experiencing conflict or communication difficulties
Families adjusting to divorce, illness, or other stressors

studies: Carr, A. (2009). The Effectiveness of Family Therapy and Systemic Interventions.
Barbato, A., & D'Avanzo, B. (2000). Family interventions in schizophrenia and psychotic disorders.
sections.limitations: Not effective when family members are unwilling to participate or when violence is ongoing.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under behavioral health benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective when preventing more intensive interventions or repeated crises.

sections.children: Helps children improve behavior and emotional regulation.
sections.adolescents: Supports identity development and conflict resolution.
sections.couples: Overlap with couples therapy in relational focus.
sections.multicultural-families: Adaptations may be necessary to align with cultural values.

items: May be delivered in systemic, structural, or strategic formats.
Therapist neutrality is essential to avoid perceived bias.
Can be combined with psychoeducation for mental illness or substance use.

items.label: Carr A. (2009). The Effectiveness of Family Therapy and Systemic Interventions.
Barbato & D'Avanzo (2000). Family interventions in schizophrenia and related disorders.

seo.description: Family Therapy helps families resolve conflict, improve communication, and strengthen relationships through systemic and relational approaches.
